bioghist.p: John Wotiz (1919-2001) was born in Czechoslovakia, and emigrated to the United States in 1939. He received his BS in chemistry from Furman University in 1941, his master's degree (on polyhydroxy amines) from the University of Richmond in 1943, and his Ph.D. (on rearrangements of acetylene compounds) from Ohio State University in 1948. Wotiz worked as a chemistry professor at the University of Pittsburgh, and then, after a period working in private industry, he went to Marshall University and finally to Southern Illinois University, where he remained until the end of his career. Wotiz had a long standing interest in the history of chemistry. He wrote a directory of international chemistry museums, and conducted chemical history tours throughout Europe (beginning in 1971). Wotiz was a long-time member of the Division of the History of Chemistry (HIST) of the American Chemical Society (ACS) and served as its chairman in 1980. He was an expert on the work and life of F. August August Kekulé, and edited The Kekulé Riddle: A Challenge for Chemists and Psychologists (1993). This work occasioned much controversy, and prior to and following its publication, Wotiz participated in several debates and panel discussions on the topic.

scopecontent.p: This collection consists of Wotiz's papers relating to his work on Kekule, his European chemical history tours and museum directory, his involvement in the Center for the History of Chemistry (CHOC), and other personal and professional papers. Kekule materials include: research files, lecture notes and slides, drafts of chapters, correspondence with authors and publishers, documents from a 1990 ACS Symposium on Kekule, and records of the professional disagreements on the thesis of his Kekule work. European chemical history tour materials include museum catalogs, brochures, itineraries, narrative reports of tour participants, and photographs. CHOC materials include correspondence, memoranda, clippings, and meeting minutes. Other papers include his master's and doctoral theses, school notes, dissertations written by his students, lecture notes for chemical history courses, and reprints of his articles.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
